trial_identification.studytitle: Glucose Targets in gestational diabetes Pilot
trial_identification.scientifictitle: An evaluation of the safety of very tight glycaemic control versus tight glycaemic control in women with gestational diabetes

interventions.interventions: Very tight glycaemic control as monitored by self blood glucose monitoring with a memory glucometer, aiming to keep fasting capillary blood glucose <5.0 mmol/L and 2 hour post prandial capillary blood glucose <6.7 mmol/L until delivery, using diet, exercise, insulin, other drugs, as necessary, and at appropriate doses to maintain the control, under the supervision of an obstetric physician and a diabetes nurse educator
interventions.comparator: Tight glycaemic control as monitored by self blood glucose monitoring with a memory glucometer, aiming to keep fasting capillary blood glucose <5.5 mmol/L and 2 hour post prandial capillary blood glucose <7.0 mmol/L until delivery, using diet, exercise, insulin, other drugs, as necessary, and at appropriate doses to maintain the control, under the supervision of an obstetric physician and a diabetes nurse educator

primaryOutcome.outcome: maternal hypoglycaemia: self monitoring capillary blood glucose <3.0 mmol/L - number of episodes, symptomatic or not.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: following initiation of diet and lifestyle changes and hypoglycaemic therapy as required until delivery

primaryOutcome.outcome: severe maternal hypoglycaemia: self monitoring capillary blood glucose <2.5 mmol/L - number of episodes.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: following initiation of diet and lifestyle changes and hypoglycaemic therapy as required until delivery

secondaryOutcome.outcome: neonatal hypoglycaemia in whole blood from heel prick <2.6 mmol/L
severe neonatal hypoglycaemia in whole blood from heel prick <2.0 mmol/L

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Pregnant women with gestational diabetes diagnosed on 75g OGTT: fasting glucose >=5.5 mmol/L and 2h glucose >=8.5 mmol/L, between 12 and 30 weeks gestation, with a singleton or twin pregnancy, not previously diagnosed as diabetic, attending antenatal care at collaborating hospitals, and giving informed written consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: >30+0 weeks gestation, or with triplets or higher order gravidity, or with major active medical disorders (including psychiatric disease requiring antipsychotic medication and inflammatory disorders requiring corticosteroid therapy, but not including chronic hypertension)

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table created by computer software
trial_design.statisticalmethods: Clinical assessment of possible increased frequency of significant maternal hypoglycaemia in intervention group This is a pilot study to assess potential issues and sample size before commencing a larger trial.

recruitment.hospital: Womens and Childrens Hospital - North Adelaide

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: 72 King William Road North Adelaide SA 5006

fundingsource.fundingname: Novo Nordisk Regional Support Scheme for 2013

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: Robinson Research Institute University of Adelaide
secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: 55 King William Road North Adelaide SA 5006

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A pilot study of maternal and neonatal outcomes of pregnancies complicated by gestational diabetes, including significant maternal hypoglycaemia and lack of neonatal hypoglycaemia: the main hypothesis is that these will not differ when receiving treatment aimed at achieving very tight blood glucose targets, compared with treatment aimed at achieving tight blood glucose targets
